titleStmt.title: The role of reinforcement learning in shaping the decision policy in methamphetamine use disorders

analytic.title: The role of reinforcement learning in shaping the decision policy in methamphetamine use disorders

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Background: The prevalence of methamphetamine use disorder (MUD) as a major public health problem has increased dramatically over the last two decades, reaching epidemic levels, which poses high costs to the health care systems worldwide, and is commonly associated with an experience-based decision-making (EDM) aberrant. However, precise mechanisms underlying such non-optimally in choice patterns still remain poorly understood. Methods: In this study, to uncover the latent neurobiological and psychological meaningful processes of such impairment, we apply a reinforcement learning diffusion decision model (RL-DDM) while methamphetamine abuser participants (n = 18, all men; mean (±SD) age: 27.3±5) and age/sex-matched healthy controls (n = 25, all men; mean (±SD) age: 26.8.0±3.63) perform choices to resolve uncertainty within a simple probabilistic learning task with rewards and punishments. Results: Preliminary behavior results indicated that addicts made maladaptive patterns of learning that mirrored in both choices and response times (RTs). Furthermore, modeling results revealed that such EDM impairment (maladaptive pattern in optimal selection) in addicts was more imputable to both increased learning rates (more sensitive to outcome fluctuations) and decreased drift rate (less reward sensitivity) compared to healthy. In addition, addicts also showed substantially longer non-decision times (attributed to slower RTs), as well as lower decision boundary criteria (reflection of impulsive choice). Conclusion: Taken together, our findings reveal precise mechanisms associated with EDM impairments in methamphetamine use disorder and confirm the debility of the options values assignment system as the main hub in learning-based decision making.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Methamphetamine abuse (MA) is one of the chronic and pervasive substance use disorders that is usually associated with different cognitive deficits including perceptual/value-based decision making and instrumen-tal learning (Hall et al., 2015;Pilhatsch et al., 2020;Smith et al., 2021;Verdejo-garcia et al., 2018;Wei et al., 2021;May et al., 2020). These two high-level complex functions respectively refer to processes such as bias that lead to specific choices and learning about response-consequence contingencies (Philiastides et al., 2006;Shanks, 1993;Sutton and Barto, 1998;Gueguen et al., 2021;Frank et al., 2004). In general terms, by merging these functions, the optimal decision requires choices that maximize reward and minimize punishment which is defective in individuals with a history of methamphetamine abuse (Dean et al., 2018;Dickinson, 1970;Verdejo-garcia et al., 2018;Wang et al., 2018;Potvin et al., 2018;Wei et al., 2021). Also, learning and perceptual aberrant in individuals with a history of substance abuse (including MA) have long-lasting effects including relapse despite the treatment they received (Konova et al., 2020;Nestor et al., 2011). Hence, having enough information about the methamphetamine abusers (MAs) ability in these complex functions helps to understand the behavioral (and underlying neurobiological and psychological) mechanisms better and as a result, improves the individualized treatment approach. Meanwhile, the strong two-way connection point of these two functions can be considered as a hub under the title of experience-based decision-making known as EDM mechanism which refers to decision processes that are influenced by feedback with rewards and/or punishments. EDM disorder due to methamphetamine use, insisting on continuing to consume the drug regardless of its negative consequences (Zhong et al., 2020;Volkow and Morales, 2015;Verdejo-garcia et al., 2018), not only limited to drug-seeking decisions but also overshadows other aspects of decision making that can be generalized to experimental tasks in the laboratory (Kluwe-Schiavon et al., 2020;Potvin et al., 2018;Wei et al., 2021;Harlé et al., 2015).

A number of prior studies have applied the probabilistic learning paradigm (as the feedback-based learning tasks) to uncover inaccurate EDM mechanisms in various patient populations including schizophrenia , attention deficit hyperactivity disorders (Pedersen et al., 2017), substance use disorders (Harlé et al., 2015;Pilhatsch et al., 2020;Wei et al., 2018) and etc. These studies have shown that EDM consists of at least three basic and interdependent sub-stages including preference formation, choice implementation, and feedback processing (Verdejo-garcia et al., 2018). Actually, previous studies including the classical computational approach to addiction have been used to uncover each of the sub-stage mechanisms separately and have observed disorders in the group of drug abusers, specifically MAs (Harlé et al., 2015;Smith et al., 2020). Here, as a minor side note, it can be mentioned that observations of these disorders are not unexpected due to the effect of methamphetamine on the dopaminergic system involved in value allocation, reward processing, and cognitive control (Fitzpatrick et al., 2021;May et al., 2020;Kohno et al., 2016;Sabrini et al., 2019;Groman et al., 2018;Kluwe-Schiavon et al., 2020;Volkow and Morales, 2015;Fitzpatrick et al., 2020). Methamphetamine has also been shown to cause serious damage to sensitive areas in decision making, such as the frontal cortex, which reinforces the expectation of observed abnormalities (Wei et al., 2018;May et al., 2020). However, understanding and investigating these defects and extracting and decomposing their underlying mechanisms in each of these three stages (and more importantly, the interaction and connection of these stages) without having a lens like cognitive modeling is very challenging and complex, or even impossible. Thus, due to computational models' potential to provide quantitative hypotheses at the neuronal and behavioral levels, using them for the optimal description of decision making and learning mechanisms are promising and helpful because they formulate underlying cognitive processes that are not readily available (Collins and Shenhav, 2022;Miletić et al., 2020). In other words, the computational modeling approach is a powerful framework to identify separable impacts of latent cognitive processes of behavior including reward and/or loss sensitivity, learning from past gains and losses, and/or erratic and impulsive choice processes (Ahn et al., 2014(Ahn et al., , 2016, while the conventional approach to analyzing behavioral performance does not allow us to break performance down into these underlying processes, nor does it even allow us to specifically identify those processes which have led to the overall performance of a task (Busemeyer and Stout, 2002;Chan et al., 2014). Two other vital points that highlight more the use of modeling for neuropsychologists and psychiatrists are that first, the introduction of computational modeling allows us to obtain much more valid behavioral predictors of types of substance use, including problems with heroin, amphetamine, cannabis, smoking, and alcohol use (see (Ahn et al., 2016(Ahn et al., , 2014Fridberg et al., 2010;Busemeyer and Stout, 2002;Keramati et al., 2017;Molloy et al., 2020) ), second, these models can detect neurocognitive markers of substance use disorders even in cases where behavior by itself is uninformative (Romeu et al., 2020;Vassileva et al., 2013).

Different models have been proposed to evaluate the performance of individuals in experiments with decision making or/and learning demands. The most popular framework for exploring the human decision-making process is evidence accumulation theory (also known as sequential sampling theory), which considers deciding as a gathering of information over time for possible choice options (Stone, 1960;Ratcliff, 1978;Ratcliff and Smith, 2004;Ratcliff et al., 2016) and can assess both the response time and accuracy simultaneously. In particular, it can be said that the most successful of these theories is the diffusion decision model (DDM) (Stone, 1960;Ratcliff, 1978), which proposes that human decisions are a stochastic process of information accumulation, continuous on the evidence space and time for each option. More precisely, the evidence from successive samples is summed, or accumulated through time until a criterion amount of evidence for one response alternative is accrued, initiating a behavioral response for that alternative. The important influential parameters in this model are the systematic tendency of the stochastic process to approach each alternative (called drift rate) as the relative speed of information accumulation in favor of alternatives, the criterion as the amount of information needed to choose each alternative (called threshold or boundary criteria), and all the time taken for processes other than evidence accumulation such as encoding stimulus and executing response (called non-decision time), please see (Ratcliff and Mckoon, 2008;Forstmann et al., 2016;Ratcliff et al., 2016;Evans and Wagenmakers, 2020) for more details. The DDM has been extensively applied in different domains of clinical and experimental psychology such as the pattern of information processing in children with ADHD (Nejati et al., 2022), perceptual decision-making in autistic children (Manning et al., 2022a), visual motion and decision-making in dyslexia (Manning et al., 2022b), evaluating the sustained attention in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) (Huang-Pollock et al., 2020), the role of speed in ADHD-related working memory deficits (Weigard and Huang-Pollock, 2017), etc. In addition to all this, which can be more important for us, is the use of DDM to understand the underlying mechanisms of decision-making deficits in substance abusers, who have used this framework well in recent studies such as evaluating choice bias and optimality of a decision in individuals with a history of heroin addiction (Scherbaum et al., 2018) and process sensory evidence during inhibitory control in individuals with cocaine use disorder (Howlett et al., 2021), etc. (Eikemo et al., 2017(Eikemo et al., , 2019.

On the other hand, there is a reinforcement learning (RL) theory to model the exploration-exploitation trade-off in instrumental learning in which a participant needs to learn features of an environment by choosing alternative actions and experiencing the outcomes of those actions in a way that maximizes the expected total value (Estes, 1950;Sutton and Barto, 1998). The model has three major parts. First, a utility function that models the subjective evaluation of the participant from reward and punishment. Second, a reinforcement learning rule which models the process of updating the objective evaluation of each option for the participant based on experienced utilities. Third, a choice probability rule that shows the participant how to behave in the next trial on the basis of the expectations for each option. Poor performance can be due to various latent neurocognitive sources. The most important ones are motivational sources (i.e. insensitive to losses (Pedersen et al., 2017)), the cognitive sources (i.e. poor learning/memory (Pedersen et al., 2017;Collins et al., 2017aGershman, 2015)) and the decision-making sources (i.e. inconsistent and less optimal choices (Daw et al., 2006;Yechiam and Busemeyer, 2005a)). Many models in the framework of reinforcement learning theory have been developed for the multi-armed bandit experiment (for example see (Fontanesi et al., 2019b;Ting et al., 2020;Palminteri and Lebreton, 2021;Lowet et al., 2020;Collins and Frank, 2012;Guitart-Masip et al., 2012;Farashahi et al., 2017;Farashahi and Soltani, 2021)), which are extensively used in vast areas of substance use disorders to understand the underlying neurocognitive dysfunctions (e.g. the exploration-exploitation trade-off, learning rate, etc.), such as (Lim et al., 2021;Ahn et al., 2014;Smith et al., 2021Smith et al., , 2020Gueguen et al., 2021;Myers et al., 2016Myers et al., , 2017.

Despite the significant advantages of these two classes of cognitive theories (i.e. evidence accumulation theory and reinforcement learning), however, each has drawbacks in explaining the whole underlying mechanisms in experience-based decision paradigms based on meaningful psychological processes. On one hand, the explanation given by traditional RL for the failure in EDM success is based on the information of the initial and final part of the EDM process (preference formation and feedback processing) and ignores the effect of the intermediate mechanism of the EDM process (dynamical choice implementation). For example, in inconsistency, the studies evaluated by RL's point addicts (including MAs) had difficulty in assigning non-optimal values to options and learning from feedback (Gueguen et al., 2021;Smith et al., 2020). Another hand, the mechanism of the middle part of the EDM process is captured by decision models such as DDM. For example, the results of this model show that non-optimal choices in addicts, despite the negative consequences they receive, may not be due to the learning system and its related parameters, and these individuals have difficulty in the cognitive system that makes optimal decisions. In other words, less sensitivity to distinguish the optimal option leads to erratic decisions and as a result, less success in the EDM success (Scherbaum et al., 2018;Weigard et al., 2021).

Due to the lack of studies that evaluate these three sub-stages in the form of an integrated system, it seems that the use of models that provide this integration is more helpful and comprehensive. We believe that since these three functions are strongly interdependent so could be described jointly by a more general theoretical framework called the reinforcement learning diffusion decision model (RL-DDM), which is a recently introduced theory (Fontanesi et al., 2019a;Miletić et al., 2020;Pedersen et al., 2017). The most important strength of this theory is the potential to provide a description of functions interaction (preference formation, choice implementation, feedback processing) (Fontanesi et al., 2019a;Miletić et al., 2020;Pedersen et al., 2017). From a more mathematical point of view, considering having evidence in past studies that the response time (RT) during learning becomes faster in normal populations, so this theory strongly supports this fact with a high correlation in addition to considering the exploration-exploitation and speed-accuracy trade-offs (Fontanesi et al., 2019a;Wiehler and Peters, 2020). Also, previous studies confirmed that RL-DDMs have more power in predicting behavior than evidence accumulation theory and reinforcement learning (Fontanesi et al., 2019a;Pedersen et al., 2017). Noteworthy, RL-DDM parameters can also have specific cognitive interpretations (and are much more comprehensive than the previous two theories)) and are considered as cognition descriptors (Pedersen et al., 2017). In particular, the amount of information needed to make a decision, information processing speed, sensitivity to options, and environment exploration to maximize utility can be mentioned as the most important components that are described by RL-DDM (Cavanagh et al., 2010(Cavanagh et al., , 2014Philiastides et al., 2006;Ratcliff et al., 2016;Voss et al., 2004). These parameters, which are derived from response time and accuracy in choices, can also be psychologically interpreted and assigned to characteristics such as self-confidence, impulsivity, caution, and other real word substance-addicted individual's behaviors (Ahn et al., 2016). Unfortunately, this nascent but comprehensive theory has not yet been comprehensively investigated in clinical applications, although recently one or two practical researches have been conducted on them, see (Pine et al., 2022;Pedersen et al., 2017;Chakroun et al., 2022;Wiehler and Peters, 2020). More importantly, in studies of addiction populations, to the best of our knowledge, this theory has not been discussed. However, based on the questions we have in this research, we believe that this theory can be the most ideal candidate for investigating the underlying neurocognitive mechanisms of experience-based decision-making in methamphetamine addicts.

This study is conducted in favor of the growing consensus on the existence of MAs-related deficits in instrumental learning and decision-making functions. To differentiate the structure of these functions, we analyzed specific learning and decision-making patterns in MAs compared to healthy individuals during probabilistic learning task performance. In fact, in this study, we are looking for the following goals. First, explore for feedback effect on response time in MAs compared to never-addicted controls. Second, validation of the applicability of the RL-DDM as a descriptor of learning and choice rule in methamphetamine abusers. Third, explore changes in underlying cognitive mechanisms based on choice and learning dynamics as revealed by RL-DDM parameters due to methamphetamine consumption. Finally, recommend model-based intervention.

div.head: Participants and procedure
div.p: Here, 25 participants with a history of methamphetamine addiction (all men; mean (±SD) age: 27.3±5) from the Government addiction camp (TEHRAN, IRAN), and 27 age and gender-matched controls (all men; mean (±SD) age: 26.8.0±3.63) with no history of substance using or other DSM disorders were recruited through social media. All participants had normal or corrected-to-normal vision and were right-handed. In addition to the self-declaration form and a psychiatrist's diagnosis based on the DSM criteria, the addiction of these participants was confirmed by the urine test upon arrival at the camp. To prevent the effects of physical pain and alleviate cognitive disorders caused by substance use, all MAs with a history of more than 21 and less than 90 days in the camp were included in the study process. Other important criteria for this initial screening for inclusion in the study include the predominance of methamphetamine consumption in individuals, no history of any neurological disorders, and not taking any medication related to mental disorders. In addition to the above, the participants were interviewed by a psychologist in terms of cognitive and psychotic's disorders, and three MA participants were excluded from the study process.

Although in this study, it was tried that the individuals of both groups were the same in terms of age and level of education, but still there were differences between groups that according to previous studies it can be effective in learning from feedback, so in Table 1, the demographic information (after considering exclusion criteria) of both groups is given. All participants provided written informed consent before starting the experiment and they were paid on average $50 (USD) as the collected points at the end of the task. Data was collected in accordance with the Helsinki federation protocol and was approved by the ethical board of the university with the ethical code of IR.SBU.REC.1400.008.

In this study, after screening and completing the Barratt Impulsiveness Scale questionnaire which measures impulsivity individuals performed a learning-based psychological task. All related instructions for task performing were presented directly on the screen step by step. In addition to providing 120 trial warm-ups, some participants' information such as age, year of abuse, and abstain days were requested before tasks. Furthermore, based on the binomial test (p < 0.05), an accuracy above 54% across 600 trials indicates that the individual did not just perform random behavior. Therefore, if the individuals' accuracy surpassed this threshold were included in the next stages of analysis. All programming codes that support the findings of this study are provided in Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/epy2d/). Also, all related data will be available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

div.head: Behavioral assessments
div.p: Different aspects of impulsivity, including non-planning, motor, and attentional aspect was measured using the Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS) (Patton et al., 1995). The BIS is a 30-item self-completion questionnaire that scored between 0 to 4 and is designed to measure these three different aspects. Higher scores in this valid questionnaire indicate greater impulsivity (Massah et al., 2019).

div.head: Experimental task design
div.p: Participants performed a modified version of the probabilistic learning task (PLT, (Frank et al., 2004)). This task whose paradigm follows a multi-armed bandit problem (Sutton and Barto, 1998) and has two phases (training and testing) examines a variety of complex cognitive functions including instrumental learning and decision making (see Figure 1), so that it has already been utilized for a better understanding of these functions in Parkinson's disease (Frank et al., 2004(Frank et al., , 2007b, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD, (Frank et al., 2007c)), autism spectrum disorder (ASD, (Solomon et al., 2015)), and schizophrenia (Doll et al., 2014). In the training phase, participants completed ten experimental blocks of 60 trials, for a total of 600 trials. In each trial of the 600 training phase trials, one of three pairs of stimuli (Japanese Hiragana character) with a different probability of being rewarded was displayed randomly on the screen (AB-BA/CD-DC/EF-FE) (see the upper half of Figure 1). More precisely, the probabilities of reward for each stimulus were according to A/B: 70%/30%, C/D: 65%/35%, and E/F: 60%/40%, for example in A/B trials, choosing A is rewarded with a probability of 0.7, whereas B is rewarded with a probability of 0.3. As a procedure, all trials began with a jittered inter-trial-interval (ITI) between 300 and 500 ms, and following it each stimulus pair was displayed randomly on the screen for 3000 ms, or until one of the stimuli in pairs selected by marked related items on the keyboard screen (Z: marked as left, M: marked as right). The result of stimulus selection was presenting "correct" or "incorrect" feedback for 750 ms (50∼100 ms post button press). If the participants do not make a choice within the 3000 ms, "No Response" was presented. Note that the participant's success in this phase was based on learning to maximize rewards throughout the task by choosing the A, C, E over the B, D, F option in each stimulus pair. An important point that should be carefully examined here is that, for example, learning to choose A instead of B can be done with three different strategies: either by learning that choosing A leads to positive feedback (reward), or by learning that choosing B leads to negative feedback (punishment), or both. To evaluate and check which strategy the participant follows, we should consider the test phase.

During the subsequent testing phase which comprised pure decision-making, all possible stimulus pairs were presented eight times for 3000ms or until to choice was made through a button press (see the bottom half of Figure 1). Each trial of this 120-trial section began with 300ms ITI. There was no sign or feedback received in the testing phase. In fact, in this phase, the participant had to use what had been learned in the training phase to get maximum accuracy for each type of combination. Choosing between these novel combinations of all stimuli in this phase allowed us to test two established cognitive effects of decision-making, i.e. Go/No-Go, and conflict effects. Actually, there are different interpretations for different combination stats and their corresponding response (Frank et al., 2004(Frank et al., , 2005(Frank et al., , 2007b. First, reward-seeking or "Go learning" (sometimes it is called positive learning) was defined as the accuracy of choosing A in AC, AD, AE, AF trials, whereas punishment avoidance or "NoGo learning" (sometimes called negative learning) was defined as the accuracy of choosing C, D, E, F in BC, BD, BE, BF trials (Frank et al., 2004(Frank et al., , 2005. Another situation designed in this phase is high conflict valenced decisions such as "win-win"(AC, AE, CE) and "lose-lose" (BC, BF, CF) test combinations having similar reinforcement values, which accuracy in these combinations considered as more choosing A and avoiding B (more reinforcing in the training phase), compared with low-conflict pairs such as "win-lose" (AD, AF, BC, BE) pairs having different reinforcement (i.e. easily discriminable) values (Frank et al., 2004;Frank, 2006;Frank et al., 2005Frank et al., , 2007b. Based on previous studies (Frank, 2006;Frank et al., 2007b), a cognitive mechanism called "hold your horses" is needed to prevent impulsivity, especially in win-win situations.
The experiment was programmed in MATLAB, using the Psychtoolbox (Brainard, 1997), and was run on a Windows PC.
Conditions:

div.head: Correct
div.p: Feedbacks Training Phase Procedure
div.formula: A C D E F B C D E F A C B D A E B F C E D F E Incorrect
div.p: Figure 1: Probabilistic learning task. On each trial of the training phase, individuals have to choose one of the stimuli of the three presented pairs. Each stimulus has a reward/punishment in probable rate and after any selection, probable feedback ("correct" or "incorrect") is presented on screen. In the testing phase, all possible combinations of stimuli are presented separately. There is no feedback provided for selection and participants should use what learned from the training phase. Psychologically, the index of reward learning and punishment avoidance coded into this section results.

div.head: Behavioral effects analysis
div.p: For examining the effect of the condition (AB/DC/EF), block (actually there are 10 blocks in which each block or bin contains 60 trials) and group, we concentrate our analysis on learning performance (i.e., mean accuracy and RTs). More precisely, here, accuracy and RTs are analyzed in two independent ANOVAs, which modeled the main effects of-and the interaction between-the experimental manipulations (i.e., condition, block, and group). In particular, we report both traditional analyses (e.g. ANOVAs) and their Bayesian counterparts (Rouder et al., 2009(Rouder et al., , 2012Morey et al., 2014). Also, to convey effect sizes, we use Cohen's d for t-tests, and η 2 for ANOVAs. On the other hand, for Bayesian analyses regarding hypothesis testing, we report the Bayes factor (BF) (Jeffreys, 1961;Kass and Raftery, 1995;Wagenmakers, 2007;Rouder et al., 2009Rouder et al., , 2012Morey et al., 2014), which is the change from prior odds to posterior odds, by defining the prior odds in favor of the null hypothesis H0 versus the alternative hypothesis H 1 as the ratio between two prior model probabilities p(H 0 )/p(H 1 ), and posterior odds as p(H 0 |D)/p(H 1 |D) updated by means of the data. Typically, a Bayes factor lower than 1 indicates support in favor of the null hypothesis, but factor of 1-3 (anecdotal) and 3-10 indicates moderate evidence in favor of the alternative hypothesis. Even further, a BF of 10-30 is considered strong evidence, and a BF larger than 30 is considered to be very strong evidence against the null hypothesis. On the other hand, to assess the learning effects in ten bins (blocks) and three conditions, we fit two separate Bayesian hierarchical regression models, a logistic regression on accuracy and a linear regression on RTs. For these models, ten levels of blocks and three levels of conditions are used to build predictors matrix to test their main effect on accuracy and RTs for separate groups. The first to tenth blocks of the training phase were coded from 1 to 10, respectively. In the same way, the condition (AB, CD, EF) were coded from 1 to 3, respectively. Also, accuracy was coded logically, such that we consider 0 if the options with the lower probability of reward were chosen (e.g., B is selected over A in AB condition), and 1 if the options with the higher probability of reward were selected (e.g., A is selected over B).

These behavioral models were fitted by PyStan 2.19 (Carpenter et al., 2017). In order to approximate the posterior distribution of the interested parameters, four parallel chains for 10000 iterations each ran. The first 5000 iterations of each chain were considered as warm-up samples and were troughed away. Furthermore, to assess models convergence, we computed the Gelman-Rubin convergence statisticsR (Gelman and Rubin, 1992). Such anR approximated to 1 indicates models successfully convergence. Hence we considered a model successfully converged ifR was less than 1.01. The Bayesian hierarchical logistic regression model of accuracy and non-informed prior distributions of parameters for each participant p and block b were as follows:
div.formula: acc b,p ∼ Bernoulli logit(c b,p x b,p θ p + c b,p γ p + x b,p β p + α p ) , α p ∼ N µ α,p , σ α,p , β p ∼ N µ β,p , σ β,p , γ p ∼ N µ γ,p , σ γ,p , θ p ∼ N µ θ,p , σ θ,p , µ α,p ∼ N (0, 2), σ α,p ∼ HN (1), µ β,p ∼ N (0, 2), σ β,p ∼ HN (1), µ γ,p ∼ N (0, 2), σ γ,p ∼ HN (1), µ θ,p ∼ N (0, 2), σ θ,p ∼ HN (1),
div.p: where x and c are block and condition coefficients and hereupon β and γ are their parameters, respectively. The parameter θ also expresses the interaction effect of block and condition. The normal (N ) prior and hyperprior distributions with average and variance parameters were used for non-variance variables. Also, half-normal distribution (HN ) prior and hyperprior distributions with standard deviation parameter were used for variance parameters. Obviously, Bernoulli is the Bernoulli distribution with the probability parameter of success. On the other hand, for the model of RT s, prior distributions were the same as the accuracy model except that the main body of the model follows
div.formula: RT b,p ∼ N c b,p x b,p θ p + c b,p γ p + x b,p β p + α p , σ ,
div.p: where σ is the noise term with the prior distribution of N (0, 2).

To assess if the block number and conditions difficulty have an effect on the accuracy and RTs, we calculated the 95% Bayesian credible interval (BCI), essentially the Bayesian analogue of a confidence interval, on the posterior mean group distribution of the parameters of interest (here regression coefficients), computed as the 95% central interval of the distributions.

div.head: Cognitive modeling
div.p: We explore the underlying mechanism of decision making and learning dynamics through a reinforcement learning diffusion decision theoretical framework which is previously proposed and empirically tested by a series of studies (Pedersen et al., 2017;Fontanesi et al., 2019a,b;Sewell et al., 2019;Miletić et al., 2020;Miletic et al., 2021). This approach which is the result of combining two powerful cognitive theories, reinforcement learning and diffusion process, can concurrently account for changes or adjustments in the relative choice probabilities over the course of an explicit learning mechanism as well as changes in response latencies driving decision-making processing. Hence, for understanding this unified theoretical framework better, it is necessary to discuss the RL and DDM in detail first.

div.head: Reinforcement learning theory
div.p: The core assumption of this category of cognitive models is that people with an internal representation of the expected value associated with each option, use these expected values for choices, and finally adjust their expected values based on the difference between the observed and expected outcomes (prediction error, PE, (Collins and Shenhav, 2022;Samson et al., 2010), which has many cognitive neuroscience supports, for example see (Montague et al., 1996;Schultz et al., 1997;). Hence, it can be said that this theory includes two main rules of update and choice policy. To be more precise, it is necessary for RL to have updating mechanism to conform to outcome expectations of choice options as a function of prediction errors with the Rescorla-Wagner rule (Rescorla and Wagner, 1972):
div.formula: Q i (t) = Q i (t − 1) + η[Outcome i (t − 1) − Q i (t − 1)].
div.p: According to the above equation, subject expectation, or equivalently, the representative value from the outcome for chosen alternative i in trial t, Q i (t), is influenced from prediction error signal, previous trial expectation and learning rate parameter (η). The PE tuned with a free learning rate parameter (0 < η < 1), so that a higher amplitude of η leads to a large fluctuation in the Q values or, in simpler terms, that each choice is affected by the rewards received in a small subset of previous trials (means giving a strong discount to previous observations), and vice versa for a small amount of η (means taking into account the observations far back). In sum, Q has a different amount for each trial and option (see the gray box of Figure 2). Note that here only the Q value of the chosen option is updated. An important point that should be mentioned here is that considering that previous studies (Gershman, 2015;Cox et al., 2015;Frank et al., 2007a) with neurocognitive support have reached the conclusion that there are differences in updating mechanism of expected rewards following positive and negative PEs, it is reasonable to include two asymmetric updating rate parameters for positive and negative reward prediction errors (Gershman, 2015) in the model, i.e. η + and η − . We consider this in the final model below. The second rule of RL models is the decision policy. RL models usually use the soft-max function which describes how participant choice between alternatives is made . This function estimates the probability P i (t) that option i will be selected over the other options j by the decision-maker:
div.formula: P i (t) = e β(t)×Qi(t) n j=1 e [β(t)×Qj (t)] ,(2)
div.p: where β supervises the participant's sensitivity to feedback and exploration-exploitation trade-off in the choice between options (Sutton and Barto, 1998;Daw et al., 2006), such that large of β cause the subject to make more deterministic choices, while low values of β allow the subject to more explore between options. The important point is that it is usually assumed that the sensitivity parameter is a function of the trial. This is because decision policies are initially based mostly on exploration, but then it gradually changes to exploitation (and exploration decreases) with learning. Various mappings function for this parameter have been presented in terms of trials, one of the most widely used of which is a power function β = (t/10) c , (Busemeyer and Stout, 2002;Yechiam and Busemeyer, 2005b), where c is the consistency parameter. Here, c is negative when sensitivity to representative value decreases across learning, and vice versa for a positive amount of c.

div.head: Diffusion decision model
div.p: In the dominant view of decision-making theories, decisions can be conceptualized as a within-trial noisy evidence accumulation process over time for possible choice options, and mathematically represented by the class of sequential sampling models (also known as evidence accumulation models), especially the diffusion decision model (DDM) as the most popular one (Stone, 1960;Ratcliff, 1978;Ratcliff and Mckoon, 2008), which assesses both the response time distribution and accuracy simultaneously as its most important capabilities. Moreover, this model assumes that the successive samples are continuously sampled and accumulated through time, and the decision to choose between alternatives make when the evidence accumulation process gradually reaches a criterion amount of evidence for one response alternative (see the blue box of Figure 2). This model assumes the RT of a chosen option knotted to four main parameters. The drift rate, v, of the diffusion process which has a mean v and standard deviation η across trials, reflects the relative speed of evidence accumulation toward the decision boundaries in favor of alternatives and is determined psychologically by the quality of the stimulus. The boundary separation parameter, a, the distance difference between upper and lower decision boundaries (options with higher and lower probability to reward in the experiment here), describes the amount of evidence necessary to respond and is considered psychologically as an index for the speed-accuracy trade-off. So, a higher amount of boundary separation leads to more accurate (i.e., a greater quantity of evidence is required to trigger a response) and slower decisions whereas a lower amount of it leads to fast and inaccurate decisions. The starting point parameter, z, indicates the point to initiate evidence accumulation toward one of the decisions boundary. Hence, the proximity of this parameter to each of the decision boundaries is psychologically interpreted as having a response bias toward a related option and varies uniformly with mean z and range s z . Note that the evidence accumulation of an unbiased decision-maker begins from z = a/2. The non-decision time parameter, T er (also written as t 0 ), describes the time consumed by stimulus encoding and motor processes. Non-decision time is assumed to vary uniformly with mean T er and range s t . Mathematically, evidence accumulation within trials is described as:

where N denotes a standard normal distribution, ∆t represents the time step, and the signed value x(t) represents evidence that is accumulated from the starting point, z, toward one of two absorbing boundaries, located at zero and a. It should be noted that in order to avoid the complexity of the models and their cognitive interpretability, in this work we do not consider across-trial variability parameters.

div.head: A unified theory of learning and decision making: Reinforcement learning diffusion decision model
div.p: As mentioned earlier, each of these two theories has weaknesses when applied to experience-based decisions, and actually are unable to express a comprehensive view of this kind of decisions and can only satisfy a part of the information. DDM provides a description of the decision-making mechanism (i.e. within-trial dynamic), whereas RL just provides an assumption about between trial dynamics, not within one. However, by introducing an integrated theory (see Figure 2), it can use the benefits of both for the benefit and complement of each other (i.g. having a more explicit theory of drift rate in DDM, having a more reasonable interpretation of the soft-max inverse temperature parameter in RL, explaining response times in RL, having trial-by-trial estimates of drift rates in DDM, etc, for more details see (Miletić et al., 2020)), as it was done well in (Pedersen et al., 2017;Fontanesi et al., 2019a) by introducing a new cognitive model called RL-DDM. The path of this unified theory is still going to be completed, for example, see (Fontanesi et al., 2019b;Sewell et al., 2019;Miletic et al., 2021). This integrated theory with its interpretable neuropsychological parameters benefits from both the advantages of diffusion theory and reinforcement learning, and the most interesting thing is that this theory has far better parameter recovery than any of the previous two models (see, for example, (Pedersen et al., 2017;Fontanesi et al., 2019a)). Similar to RL, this integrative theory assumes that subjective values associated with the alternatives are updated after experiencing outcomes, i.e. Q values are updated as a function of the reward prediction errors based on a learning rate parameter (Eq.

(1)). On the other hand, due to the strong supporting evidence ( (Busemeyer and Stout, 2002) can be seen as one of the examples) that showed that the sensitivity may change for various cognitive reasons (i.g. due to changes in exploitation-exploration trade-off, or increased fatigue) during the learning process, instead of a soft-max function, the diffusion decision model as a within-trial dynamical theory is considered as a choice process in this unified theory, such that the next trial speed of evidence accumulation (i.e. drift rate) influenced from the difference between updated subjective values and scaling parameter:
div.formula: v(t) = [Q cor (t) − Q inc (t)] • v constant ,(4)
or v(t) = [Q cor (t) − Q inc (t)] .(t/10) vpower ,(5)
div.p: where v(t) is the time-varying trial to trial drift rate as a function of the difference in the expected rewards Q cor and Q inc of the options. According to the above equations, more differences between the value of options expectations lead to faster and more accurate decisions. Traditionally, by a little regularity in the choices, this difference comes to account after receiving several outcomes (i.e. trials (t)). Another point that draws attention here is the existence of a scaling parameter , i.e. v constant and/or v power , which can capture sensitivity to value difference. Briefly, on one hand, considered Eq. (4) as estimator of v(t) is consistent with the hypothesis that there is a linear and constant mapping between the value difference and v(t). On the other hand, estimate v(t) using Eq. (5) traces the effect of learning (as the task progressed) on the accumulation process and therefore sensitivity to value difference. Note that higher values of v constant and v power lead to more sensitivity to value difference. Also, it is important to note here that these simple transformations are considered as a replacement for the sensitivity parameter in simple RL. Another thing to consider, which should be looked at a little deeper here, is the non-linear power function in Eq. (5) and the role of the consistency parameter v power in that function. In fact, it can be seen that when the confidence and consequently the drift rate increases during learning, the consistency parameter v power will be positive, and vice versa when the confidence in the learned values decreases due to some cognitive reasons such as fatigue, the consistency parameter v power will be negative. In a more precise way, it can be said that this nonlinear mapping shows the role of exploration-exploitation trade-off well. In addition to these two mentioned mechanisms which are summarized based on two parameters learning rate and a scaling parameter v constant (or in other versions as v power ), it can be said that this unified theory has two other mechanisms which are coded in the well-known parameters of the non-decision time T er and a threshold a. In this theory, the mechanism related to the threshold parameter can be viewed from two perspectives, it can be fixed or trial-by-trial modulated over the course of learning because speed-accuracy updated through learning, i.e. a(t) = a base + (t/10) a mod ,

where a base is the baseline decision boundary, and considering a mod equals zero is a reflection of no decision boundary alteration as learning progresses. However, assigning value to a mod , boundary separation alteration by learning comes to account (by trials (t)). Note that, because the position of options randomly changes between sides of the screen there is no bias considered in such models.

div.head: Experimental details
div.p: As outlined above, in this experiment RL-DDM was used to uncover between-and within-trial neurocognitive mechanisms in the training phase. Various underlying mechanisms based on this unified theory can be provided by combining the parameters. In practice, because different mechanisms can be assigned to the model, we fitted a total of eight variations of RL-DDM with distinct mechanisms and compared them to check quantitated their abilities to explain data, see Table 2. For all RL-DDM models (which were fit using PyStan 2.19), parameters were estimated using a hierarchical Bayesian framework due to the various advantages and strengths of this approach rather than the conventional counterparts (for details, it is recommended to see (Wetzels et al., 2010;Vandekerckhove et al., 2011;Lee and Wagenmakers, 2014) ). This framework updates the prior distribution of model parameters on the basis of the data fed to the model to provide posterior distributions of parameters, where each participant's individual parameters are drawn from group-level truncated normal distributions, see Appendix A for more insight about prior distributions for parameters and also a graphical representation of the Bayesian hierarchical modeling of all eight variations of proposed RL-DDMs. Our analysis also generated full posterior distributions of the model parameters at both individual and group levels via Markov-chain Monte Carlo(MCMC) sampling (Gelman et al., 1996). Again, to assess convergence between chains, Gelman-Rubin convergence statics (R) is computed. Importantly,R < 1.01 consider as a good convergence criterion in the chains. Then, due to the variability of the complexity of the models, we started with 1000 samples (500 samples as a warm-up) for all models, and if there was no convergence (R < 1.01), the number of samples increased and checked the convergence again. Finally, after comparing all eight models for each group of participants, the best model in each group was run with four chains with 8000 samples and 4,000 samples warm-up each.

Eventually, as a model fit measure, posterior predictive checks (Gelman et al., 1996) estimated for mean accuracy and mean RT for each condition during blocks and searched whether the 95% Bayesian credible interval (BCIs) of the posterior predictive distributions contained the participants mean accuracy and RT for Figure 2: Reinforcement learning diffusion decision model. As illustrated in the blue box, after stimulus presentation in each trial (for example, AB), the encoding process starts and a few millisecond later evidence accumulation begins at the starting point (z) and specific rate (v). The accumulation process continues until its trajectories touch one of the two decision boundaries (a), also this process is considered as decision time. One of the two options is selected after making a decision and spending milliseconds for the motor response. The selected options with an assigned probability rate determined for the outcome to "correct" or "incorrect" feedback update the subjective value for the next trial. Gray box: Feedbacks update the expected value of selected options. Also learning rate (η) as an independent component influenced this update. Hence, during the course of learning each expected option value (Q-values) is updated separately (for example, A as the correct option and B as the incorrect one). Importantly, these Q-values update the next trial drift rate (v). Also, decision threshold (a) can be fixed or updated by trials. Therefore, learning can lead to faster and more accurate decisions. AB, CD, and EF. This approach provides an advantageous measure to assess the property of models in their capability to predict patterns observed in the data. To estimate the posterior predictive distributions, 500 samples were chosen from the posterior distribution, generated 500 independent datasets, and then calculated the mean accuracy and mean RTs in each dataset, separately for choice pairs during blocks. Therefore, to assess model fit, we looked at to overlap between observed RT and accuracy of separated pairs with Bayes factors and 95% BCI of estimated posterior predictive for RT and accuracy in corresponding pairs during blocks.

Finally as mentioned earlier, we compared RL-DDM models with widely applicable information criterion (WAIC) and estimated log pointwise predictive density (lppd) (Watanabe, 2013). Generally, in model comparison less amount of WAIC and high amount of lppd indicate better fits (see (Gelman et al., 2013) for more details). Note that accuracy is defined as choosing A, C, E over B, E, F and coded as a logical number in the data frame (0, 1). Also, non-responses and RTs faster than 200 ms were removed before the main analysis.

div.head: Results
div.p: By exclusion criteria mentioned in the previous section, 43 participants (healthy control (HC) = 25, MA = 18) data included in the main analysis procedure, see Table 1. Also, on average 0.045 of the data from healthy people and 0.05 of the data from addicted people were removed before the main analysis based on the response time exclusion criteria (for HCs: 27 (SD = 0.04) trials; for MAs: 30 (SD = 0.07) trials). As can be seen, the mean accuracy of included participants for the control and MA groups were 0.67 (SD = 0.09) and 0.62 (SD = 0.07), respectively. These means for response time were 1.13 (SD = 0.25) for the control and 1.27 (SD = 0.26) for the MA group. Note that these conventional measures (i.e. accuracy and response time) were statistically analyzed via mixed (Bayesian) ANOVA on the related score with both condition types (AB, CD, EF) and blocks as the within-subject factor, and also groups (HC vs. MA) as the between-subject factor.

div.head: Behavioral results
div.p: Averaged training phase accuracy shift during trials or bins (blocks) is interpreted as a learning effect. This measure results for both groups (averaged in all conditions) are shown in Figure 3a. It seems that compared to MAs, the control group's performance was more affected by learning, such that their mean score varied as bins, from 0.56 (the first bin) to 0.75 (last bin) for HC and from 0.53 (the first bin) to 0.65 (last bin) for MA group. In trade-off with accuracy, mean RTs corresponding to the group also become faster as bins. This shift is more explicit in the control group (from 1.32s in the first bin to 0.98s in the last bin) compare to MA (1.41s in the first bin to 1.19s in the last bin), see Figure 3b. The average accuracy during the whole trials for each condition can also be considered as another measure of learning. This criterion only provides information about the difficulty effect between conditions not within the learning procedure, see Figure 3c. Statistically, as mixed (Bayesian) ANOVA confirmed, the main effect of group (F (1, 41) = 3.7, p = 0.06, η 2 = 0.029, BF = 1.4) and interactions between group and condition on the accuracy score (F (2, 82) = 2.9, p = 0.06, η 2 = 0.045, BF = 2.3) were not significant while significant difference found between conditions accuracy score (F (2, 82) = 11.57, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.16, BF > 100). Also, one-way repeated measure ANOVA revealed the accuracy score was significantly different at the different conditions for both groups (for HC: F (2, 48) = 9, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.2, BF > 100 and for MAs: F (2, 34) = 6.8, p = 0.003, η 2 = 0.2, BF = 31). Next, post-hoc analyses with a Bonferroni adjustment revealed that two pairwise differences, between conditions were statistically significantly different (p < 0.01), such that HC individuals were more accurate to choose AB to compare to CD (t(24) = 4.4, p.adj < 0.001, BF > 100) and EF (t(24) = 3.4, p.adj = 0.006, BF = 19). Such significant effects were only founded for AB-CD (t(17) = 3, p.adj = 0.02, BF = 6.4) and EF-CD (t(17) = −3, p.adj = 0.02, BF = 5.7) not AB-EF in MAs. Finally by considering between-group effects (in the conventional form of ANOVA), compared to MAs, HC participants significantly were more accurate only in AB conditions (F (1, 41) = 8.3, p = 0.006, η 2 = 0.18, BF = 7.2) neither CD (F (1, 41) = 1, p.adj = 0.9, η 2 = 0.02, BF = 0.45) nor EF (F < 1, BF = 0.37), see Figure 3c, and Table 1. Finally, to evaluate if there is a three-way interaction between accuracy in blocks (or bin which includes 60 trials), conditions, and group for accuracy score three-way mixed ANOVA was conducted (group as between-condition and block as within-subjects factors). Accordingly, the main effect of the condition was significant (F (2, 82) = 11.5, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.08) and neither the main effect of the group (F (1, 41) = 3.7, p = 0.06,η 2 = 0.01) nor any of the interactions involving the group were significant ( group × block F (4, 161) = 1.2, p = 0.2, η 2 = 0.006; group × condition F (2, 82) = 2.9, p = 0.06, η 2 = 0.02; group × condition × block F < 1). Also, the main effect of the block was significant (F (4, 161) = 11.5, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.05) with accuracy increasing from block 1 to 10 (t(125) = 5, p < 0.001). Briefly, as compared to MAs, control group accuracy significantly was better in the last block (t(122) = 2.8, p = 0.005). Also, the block interaction with condition was not significant, F < 1, indicating that the rate of learning across blocks was similar for the three conditions.

Again, as estimated by mixed (Bayesian) ANOVA, both the main effect of condition (F (2, 82) = 14.7, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.029, BF > 100) and interactions between group and condition on the RTs (F (2, 82) = 7.5, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.015, BF = 17) were significant while no significant main effect of the group founded (F (1, 41) = 3.2, p = 0.08, η 2 = 0.029, BF = 2.1). Also, one-way repeated measure ANOVA revealed the RTs was significantly different at the different conditions for both groups (for HC: F (2, 48) = 9.1, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.03, BF = 61 and for MAs: F (2, 34) = 14.2, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.05, BF > 100). As mentioned above and in trade-off with accuracy, post-hoc analyses with a Bonferroni adjustment revealed that HCs RT become faster at the same time, such that they were faster in choosing AB compared to CD (t(24) = −4.62, p.adj < 0.001, BF > 100) and EF (t(24) = −2.66, p.adj = 0.007, BF = 6.5). This effect was slightly different for the MA group and they were faster in choosing AB compared to CD (t(17) = −3.97, p.adj = 0.003, BF = 37) and CD compared to EF (t(17) = 4.7, p.adj < 0.001, BF > 100). Further, by considering between-group effects, compared to MAs, the HC group significantly showed faster RT only in AB (F (1, 41) = 5.38, p = 0.02, η 2 = 0.11, BF = 2.4) and CD (F (1, 41) = 4.5, p = 0.03, η 2 = 0.1, BF = 1.7) conditions, not EF (F < 1, BF = 0.3), see Figure 3d, and Table 1.

As for accuracy, to more investigation of the three-way interaction between block, condition, and group for RT we use three-way mixed ANOVA. The main effect of the group was not significant (F (1, 41) = 3.2, p = 0.08, η 2 = 0.04) but its interaction with the condition was significant (F (2, 82) = 6.8, p = 0.002, η 2 = 0.009), see the aforementioned post-hoc analysis for this interaction. Again, the main effect of the block was significant (F (3.5, 144) = 11.36, p < 0.001, η 2 = 0.05) but none of the interactions involving the block were significant (group × block F (3.5, 144) = 1.2, p = 0.3, η 2 = 0.007; block × condition F < 1; group × condition × block F (9.6, 396) = 1.4, p = 0.16, η 2 = 0.005). Next, as the follow-up study estimated, RT speed increased from blocks 1 to 10 (t(123) = 5.1, p < 0.001). Also, as compared to MAs, HCs RT significantly was faster in the last block (t(114) = −4, p < 0.001).

For more investigation, to test blocks and conditions' effects on accuracy and RTs, we fit two regression models. Logistic regression results on accuracy confirm that blocks and conditions, but not their interaction, have effects on accuracy in the HC group. The 95% BCI was higher than 0 (0.43 to 0.84, M = 0.063) for the mean group block coefficient (meaning that HCs were more accurate in the last blocks), lesser than 0 for the mean group condition coefficient (-0.26 to -0.15, M =-0.2; meaning that HCs were less accurate in difficult conditions), and it also was around 0 for the interaction coefficient in HC group (-0.01 to 0.006, M = −0.002). Logistic regression results on accuracy were slightly different for the MA group, whereas only blocks neither conditions nor interaction (between conditions and blocks) have an effect on accuracy. The 95% BCI was higher than 0 (0.014 to 0.058, M = 0.03) for the mean group block coefficient (meaning that similar to HCs, MAs were more accurate in the last blocks) and was around 0 for the mean group condition coefficient (-0.04 to 0.08, M = 0.017) and for the interaction coefficient (-0.01 to 0.008, M = -0.002); see Figure 4 for more insight.

In addition, the linear regression model on RTs suggests that both blocks and conditions, but not their interaction, have effects on RTs in both groups. Specifically, the 95% BCI was lesser than 0 for the mean group block coefficient (for HCs: -0.04 to -0.02, M = -0.03; for MAs: -0.03 to -0.01, M = -0.02; all participants' speed of response increased as block progress). Furthermore, the condition affects participants' behavior differently. Such, the 95% BCI was higher than 0 for the mean group condition coefficient in HCs (0.03 to 0.07, M = 0.05; meaning that HCs were slower in response to difficult conditions) and lesser than 0 for the mean group condition coefficient in MAs (-0.05 to 0.003, M = -0.029; meaning that MAs were faster in response to difficult conditions), and was around 0 for interaction coefficient in both group (for HCs: −0.004 to 0.002, M = −0.001; for MAs: −0.003 to 0.004, M = −0.0006). This block and condition effects are in the line of accuracy-RT trade-off. Finally, in between-group comparison, HCs' accuracy were more affected by both the block (BF=22) and condition (BF>100), and their response times were also affected more by block (BF<1/100) and condition (BF>100).

div.head: Fitting and model comparison
div.p: To gain a deeper understanding of the experience-based decision processes, we compared eight RLLD models with different mechanisms assumed on data from 25 HC and 18 MA in the learning phase of our task using some well-known criteria called WAIC, pWAIC, and lppd, see Table 2. Taking a closer look at the results reported in this table, we can say that among the given models for both groups, the better models in predicting participant's behaviors are including separate learning rates (η) to fit for positive and negative prediction errors, also boundary threshold modulated by learning, see Eqs. 4,5,6. Quantitatively, the model ranking differed with respect to the type of drift rate over the course of learning (be constant or altered as power function) for each group. For addicts (MAs), the model with constant drift rate (RL-DDM4) slightly provided the best account of the data (has high predictive accuracy) whereas, in healthy the data were best accounted for by a model with altering drift rate, RL-DDM8. Although in the quantitative process of model comparison less amount of WAIC and the highest amount of lppd are signs of the best model, but, as our data illustrated, these criteria sizes are very close among models (see Table 2). Therefore it seems that model selection only using quantitative tests is not reliable and qualitative comparison (i.e., visual inspection of whether our model captured the observed patterns in our data) is recommended. Hence, in addition to quantitative comparison, qualitative tests for both groups (MAs .vs HCs) across the models are implemented and models are ranked more precise (this qualitative analysis is carried out in Section 3.2.2). Next, the "1st" ranked model was examined for both groups in the main part, and the corresponding analysis for the alternative model ("2th") in Appendix C. Table 2: Quantitative model comparison of the different reinforcement learning diffusion decision models (RL-DDMs) for both groups separately. The model could include a single or dual learning rate (η), constant or power drift rate (v), and fixed or modulated boundary separation (a). WAIC: widely applicable information criterion, pWAIC: the effective number of parameters, lppd: the log predictive accuracy of the fitted model to data (Gelman et al., 2013).

div.head: Posterior predictive checks
div.p: Posterior predictive check is a powerful lens to examine whether RL-DDM captures the main feature in the observed data, specifically changes in accuracy and RT over the course of learning (Gelman et al., 2013). Due to the slight similarity between the two models (RL-DDM4 and RL-DDM8), especially for addicts, a qualitative comparison is helpful to determine the most optimal model. So, we simulated data from 500 parameter sets of the joint posterior distribution in RL-DDMs, binned the trials (each bin contains 25 trials across the conditions) and calculated mean RTs and accuracies for each bin among 500 simulated full data sets separately for MAs and HCs, see Figure 5 for RL-DDM4 and Appendix C, Figure 12 for RL-DDM8. It is clear that the qualitative comparison shows that RL-DDM4 is more capable of capturing observed behavior for both groups, especially addicts. Also, compared to the RL-DDM8 model with a constant drift rate (RL-DDM4) less tended to overestimate difficult conditions (i.e. CD). Hence, due to our goal (select the best model to describe MAs behavior), the principle of parsimony (Vandekerckhove et al., 2015), quantitative and qualitative tests, we examined RL-DDM4 for both groups in the main body and corresponding analysis for RL-DDM8 is investigated in Appendix C. As illustrated in Figure 5, in addition to the ability of RL-DDM4 in capturing the accuracy (increase) and RT (decrease) as learning effects over time (for both groups), also this model can slightly capture the conditions difficulty effects for the healthy group (AB .vs CD, EF) well. To be more confident about our fitting posterior predictive checks, we also considered RT quantiles (see Figure 6). Moreover, model estimation for mean accuracy and response time for each condition is provided separately (see Figure 7). These results also reproduced with RL-DDM8 (Appendix C, Figures 12, 13, and 14). Note that modulations in RTs over bins were due to learning and that changes in both v (increase) and a (decrease) over time contributed to changes in RTs (see the discussion).

div.head: Group differences in RL-DDM parameters
div.p: We next investigated group differences in the parameters of the RL-DDM4 in detail. This measure helps to assess how the participants are different in performance by inference on model parameters (Wetzels and Wagenmakers, 2012). By considering previous studies for Bayes factors, between-subjects comparison demonstrated evidence that compared to healthy, MA subjects have more positive (decisive) and negative learning rate (decisive) and non-decision time (substantial) parameters whereas the control group has slightly Figure 5: Posterior predictive checks of mean accuracy and RT according to the RL-DDM4 for both groups separately. The solid line represented the observed accuracy (left column) and RT (right column) data for HC(a) and MA(b). Observed data are compared to the 95% Bayesian credible interval (BCI) of the posterior predictive distribution (shaded areas) for each stimulation pair and for bins of trials within the first phase of the task. more baseline (substantial), modulated boundary separation criteria (substantial) and drift rate scaling (decisive) parameter (see Figure 8 and Table 3). Finally, to examine the expected individual's performance parameters correlation with mean posterior model parameters corresponding analysis for RL-DDM4 results can be found in Figure 9. However, the mean of optimal selection was not significantly correlated with measures of age and BIS at individual levels (all |r| < 0.30).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Here we implemented the prediction error task in combination with statistical and computational models to uncover the underlying mechanism of malformed patterns for both learning and choice dynamics in methamphetamine abusers. For these purposes, we assessed the effects of trials across all conditions by fitting regression models on accuracy and RT. We observed a trial effect on both accuracy and RTs for both groups differently. On the other hand, the primary behavioral analysis estimated less optimal choices and as a result maladaptive patterns of learning in addicts. These preliminary findings suggest such impairments should be investigated in both optimal feedback learning and decision dynamics. Hence, for a more straightforward interpretation, between group parameters comparison of RL-DDM as the comprehensive model which decomposes both learning and decision dynamics come into account. Modeling evidence, particularly quantitative checks, suggests that RL-DDMs with separated learning rates and boundary modulated thresholds are better for both healthy and addicts and regenerated observed patterns of accuracy and RTs over the course of trials. However, choosing the best model for each group according to the type of drift parameter is controversial and qualitative measures suggest overcoming such challenges. Finally, as tested by posterior predictive checks the model with a constant drift rate provide the best fitting (less tendency to over/underestimation), and selectivity for addicts. This model suggestion is in line with a previous successful study for another group with EDM difficulty (Pedersen et al., 2017). . Note that the bold gray (light) shadowed areas in lower distributions represent the 85% (95%) BCI, see Table 3 for more details.

div.head: Learning rate: Faster and more sensitive
div.p: Between groups comparison revealed, relative to healthy controls, addicts have more positive and negative learning rates. Although these differences may seem inconsistent while MAs were less accurate than HCs, on one hand, it is critical to note that a higher amount of learning rate in addition to having a correlation with faster learning reflected more sensitivity to random alterations in the outcomes. On the other hand, Figure 9: Correlation results for RL-DDM4. Individual performance parameters correlation with the mean posterior of model parameters for both groups (blue: healthy, red: addict) for overall accuracy (Upper panels) and RT (lower panels). implicitly, this difference refers to addicts more rely on recent outcomes (considered more weight to new information and earlier consequence are less accounted for) (Ekhtiari et al., 2017). With debates, this finding has been replicated in other groups of addicts by methods that did not take into account the dynamics of decision making in the computational model (Ahn et al., 2014;Gueguen et al., 2021;Haines et al., 2018;Smith et al., 2020). Also, in association with decision parameters, higher drift scaling (v constant ) is required to compensate for lower learning rate effects and hence apparent learning successes effectiveness of learning rate. Therefore, it makes sense to see an increased v constant in RL-DDM4 for HCs compared to MAs.

div.head: Drift rate: Jumping to decision
div.p: Generally, the drift rate parameter as an important variable of decisions during learning provides an explanation of how fast one accumulates recently received information to make a decision. In RL-DDMs, the drift rate parameter is a reflection of different expected values (for correct option vs. incorrect option) and is highly tuned by learning rates. Hence, sensitivity to value differences is coded in the drift parameter (v constant ). As RL-DDM4 results estimated, compared to MAs, sensitivity to options values increased in HCs, meaning that optimal options were chosen over non-optimal options more deterministically in HCs. In another word, this observed decrease in MAs indicates that the patients decide more erratically. This effect was previously reported on other addict groups and is in the line with unstable response rules reported in contexts of feedback learning (Ahn et al., 2014;Fitzpatrick et al., 2020;Harlé et al., 2015;Scherbaum et al., 2018;Wiehler and Peters, 2020). Also, sensitivity to reward decreasing in the patient group can be due to the methamphetamine effects on the options value updating network including both medial prefrontal cortex(dorsal/ventral rote) and frontostriatal connectivity (Bartra et al., 2013;London et al., 2015;Lopez-Gamundi et al., 2021). On the other hand, according to the opponent actor learning model, disturbs that methamphetamine makes to the dopaminergic network, downregulates dopamine, can reduce the sensitivity to reward Nagano-Saito et al., 2012;Robertson et al., 2016;Shukla and Vincent, 2021).

Another reason for MAs infirmity in distinguishing optimal options can be due to their poor working memory (Sabrini et al., 2019). To reconcile with the working memory lacking, recent studies have shown that the decision values may be maintained in the working memory, so it can be argued that more capacity in working memory results in better distinguishing of options and hence more reward sensitivity (Collins et al., 2017b;Yoo and Collins, 2022). Finally, a strong positive correlation between the drift-rate scaling parameter and accuracy at the individual level (t(41) = 9.5, ρ = 0.87, p < 0.001) confirms the important role of the value expectation updating process in guiding adaptive decisions and hence learning success.

div.head: Boundary separation criteria: Time as the price of accurate decision
div.p: In addition to slightly higher baseline boundary separation (a base ), which provides an estimation of initial speed-accuracy trade-off, in healthy the nonlinear term of boundary separation (a mod ), which modulated through the course of the experiment, more quickly decreased as compared to MAs (a mod is more negative for HC group).

As compared to MAs, why do HCs have higher boundary separation criteria (a)? This question is not so easy to answer as MAs suffer from a variety of cognitive deficits including impulsivity (Fitzpatrick et al., 2020(Fitzpatrick et al., , 2021Sabrini et al., 2019). As an explanation regarding impulsive behavior in MAs as in other impulsive patients (ADHD), a higher value of this parameter indicates that HCs spend more time making decisions (their responses are given after sufficient evidence accumulation), so unlike addicted people, they do not make impulsive decisions (Frank et al., 2007b;Pedersen et al., 2017). Another vigorous explanation for this question can be tied to computational models that align with the disturbances that methamphetamine has on the dopaminergic system and other regions involved in decision making (medial prefrontal cortex including the anterior cingulate cortex, striatum and generally corticostriatal pathway) (Krause et al., 2017;Nagano-Saito et al., 2012;Shukla and Vincent, 2021). On the one hand, computational models demonstrated medial prefrontal regions, including the anterior cingulate cortex as a key region in performance monitoring, continuously code stimulus-response links based on passed trials, and when participants are forced to the choice between options with ambiguous values this uncertainty evokes a fast signal via the corticosubthalamic pathway to uplift the decision threshold and hence response cautions (Cavanagh et al., 2011(Cavanagh et al., , 2014. On the other hand, individual differences in modulate trial-to-trial response thresholds can be coded in corticostriatal pathway activity (see (Frank et al., 2015) to an overview; (London et al., 2015;Sabrini et al., 2019). To reconcile with these studies, mathematical modeling demonstrated deficit (in healthy individuals) (Peters and D'Esposito, 2020) and attenuated activity in the ventral rote of the medial prefrontal cortex (in addicts) (Wiehler and Peters, 2020) thought to be coded into baseline boundary and boundary modulated parameters respectively. Again, these modeling results point to the association of the representation of decision values with the threshold subcomponents of the decision boundary.

In nutshell, compared to MAs, the healthy subjects were more focused on accuracy instead of speed, and their needed evidence to make decisions more decayed over time. Also, the injuries from methamphetamine consumption on decision-related networks cause MAs to be aberrant in adjusting the decision threshold to obtain the maximum reward.

div.head: Non-decision time: Encoding and execution
div.p: The non-decision time (T er ) is slightly faster as part of the observed response time in HCs compared to MAs. This effect suggested the HCs spend less time on stimulus encoding and motor-related processes. Meeting this effect is in line with dopaminergic system impairment in MAs, as well as converges with previous observations of both encoding and motor execution dullness in methamphetamine abusers (Hall et al., 2018;Volkow et al., 2001;Wollman et al., 2019). Also, this parameter reduction in MAs consistent with mathematically model components of other addict groups (Van Ravenzwaaij et al., 2012).

div.head: General discussion
div.p: All in all, RL-DDM modeling subtleties demonstrated the addict's high sensitivity to outcomes (coded in learning rate parameters), premature decisions namely 'impulsive information processing' (measured by decision-threshold subcomponents), and impairment in motor response/encoding impairments (reflected in non-decision time parameter). In another hand, extreme poverty in sensitivity to reward (coded in drift-rate scaling parameter) was observed in MAs.

Nevertheless, an important question remained. Which components are responsible for the difficulty in learning success in such prediction error tasks? Answering is a bit debated while various and integrated processes have an effect on learning success; but in combination with RL-DDM, it seems that the debility in options values assignment system, selectivity drift rate scaling as a reflection of between option differentiator parameter plays a critical role in learning success. Alongside this suggestion, a previous longitudinal study suggested subjective value differences can provide an estimation of the risk of addiction (Weigard et al., 2021).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In summary, RL-DDM provides a richer description of cognitive mechanisms underpinning learning and decision-making. This interaction may be lost in the traditional models of response time and choice data, DDM, and RL model. According to RL-DDM, sub-optimal decisions in MAs appear to be due to both greater sensitivity to random fluctuations in the payoffs and less reward sensitivity (infirmity to distinguish optimal options). The finding helps to elucidate the cause of MAs' difficulty in adjusting adaptive patterns of behavior. More experiments should be conducted to both enhance MAs abilities to be less sensitive in facing choice-outcomes fluctuations and reward sensitivity (assign more value to optimal options). Finally, these findings should be reconfirmed at the individual level while considering other effective covariates such as working memory, and attention. We hope these findings could help us to open a new window for treatments of addiction. div.head: Appendix A: Bayesian hierarchical reinforcement learning drift diffusion model
div.p: The Bayesian hierarchical full reinforcement learning diffusion decision model(RLDDM) is specified as a graphical representation in Figure 10. The model priors and hyper-priors were determined as follows:

where η (+/−) are the learning rate for positive/negative prediction error. The N is a normal distribution parameterized by mean and standard deviation parameters and HN is a half-normal distribution parameterized by standard deviation, and W iener is the wiener distribution with parameters drift, boundary separation, non-decision time and relative starting-point equal to 0.5.

It should be noted that the mentioned graphical representation covers both models 4 and 8 (see Table 2) by changing the shape of the drift parameter (placing v constant or v power instead of Ω).
